title: El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail: Management
body: Explore This Park    Learn About the Park     Management             Management        Established in 2000 404 miles long (2013)      Establishing a New National Historic TrailAdded to the National Trails System in October 2000, El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro (Royal Road of the Interior) National Historic Trail recognizes the primary route between the colonial Spanish capital of Mexico City and the Spanish provincial capitals at San Juan de Los Caballeros (1598-1600); San Gabriel (1600-1609); and Santa Fe (1610-1821). The national historic trail extends 404 miles from El Paso, Texas, to Ohkay Owingeh, New Mexico. Bureau of Land ManagementBLM coadministers this trail with the National Park Service. To learn more about BLM trail activities go to: www.blm.gov/nm/st/en/prog/recreation/el_camino_real_de.html CertificationFind out the benefits of certifying your El Camino Real site; become one of our partners!     National Trails System The National Historic Trails System, established by the National Trails System Act of 1968, commemorates historic routes and promotes their preservation and development for public use. National historic trails recognize diverse facets of history such as prominent past routes of exploration, migration, trade, communication, and military action. The historic trails generally consist of remnant sites and trail segments, and thus are not necessarily contiguous. Although national historic trails are administered by federal agencies, land ownership may be in public or private hands. Learn more about the National Trails System, including national historic, scenic, and recreation trails. View the National Trails System map.      Our Mission To promote the preservation and development of national historic trails for public use, enjoyment, education, and inspiration.      Our Staff & Offices Laws & Policies
